content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Lauren Kallas: I was born and raised in Chicago, in a neighborhood that was pretty diverse even back then. My parents were both working-class, and they divorced when I was pretty young, so I grew up in a single-parent household with my mom. She worked full-time as a receptionist, and she always made sure I had what I needed, even if we weren't rolling in money. I remember being a pretty quiet kid, more interested in books than in playing outside. I was raised Catholic, but I haven't been religious since I was in high school. I always felt like I didn't quite fit in with the more traditional parts of the church, and I guess that's when I started questioning a lot of things. I went to college on a scholarship, eventually earning a graduate degree in social work. It wasn't easy—I worked part-time through most of it, and I had to take out a lot of loans. But I wanted to help people, especially those who had it harder than I did. I've been working full-time now for a few years, and while I'm not where I want to be financially, I feel like I'm on the right path.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Lauren Kallas: There was definitely a crossroads, and it came during my junior year of college. I was working part-time at a community center, helping out with after-school programs for kids from low-income families. One of the kids, a boy named Marcus, had a really tough home life—his mom was struggling with addiction, and he was bouncing between foster homes. I got really close to him, and I remember one day he just looked at me and said, 'You're the only one who ever really listens to me.' That hit me hard. I had always thought I was doing this to help people, but that moment made me realize how much of an impact even small acts of kindness and presence could have. Around the same time, I was offered a job at a nonprofit that paid better but didn't align with my passion for direct service. I had to choose between stability and staying true to my purpose. I chose the latter. It was scary, and I had to take on more debt, but I knew that if I walked away from that path, I might never forgive myself. That decision shaped who I am today—it reinforced my belief that meaningful work is worth the struggle, even when the road is hard.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Lauren Kallas: I think it was a conscious choice, but not in the way most people might expect. I didn't sit down and make a list of pros and cons like I've seen in movies or books. It was more like a quiet realization that I couldn't walk away from the kind of work that made me feel alive, even if it meant sacrificing comfort. I remember lying awake at night, thinking about Marcus and the other kids I worked with, and I kept coming back to the same question: 'What kind of person do I want to be?' I didn't want to be someone who chose the easy path just because it was safer. I wanted to be someone who showed up, even when it was hard. So I made the choice—not because I had all the answers, but because I knew I couldn't live with myself if I didn't.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Lauren Kallas: Absolutely. I remember talking to a professor of mine, Dr. Alvarez, who had been through similar struggles. She didn't just teach me about social work theory—she lived it. She took me under her wing and encouraged me to keep going, even when I felt like I was barely keeping my head above water. She also connected me with a mentorship program at the local community center, which gave me the confidence to stick with my path. And then there was the support from the kids I worked with. They reminded me why I was doing this in the first place. Without those people—without that network of support—I don't know if I would have had the strength to make the choice I did. It's funny, though, because I think a lot of people underestimate how much a single person can impact another's life. Sometimes, all it takes is someone who believes in you when you can't believe in yourself.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Lauren Kallas: I don't have a partner or children right now, but my family is still a big part of my life. My mom is the most important person in it—she's been my rock through everything. Even though we didn't have a lot growing up, she always made sure I felt loved and supported. We don't talk about the harder parts of our past much, but I know she's proud of me for the work I do. I also have a few cousins who live in the area, and we keep in touch. They're all in different stages of life—some are still in school, others are working, but we always make time for each other during holidays or big events. I think family, for me, is about showing up, even when life gets complicated. I don't know what the future holds in terms of relationships or starting a family of my own, but I know I want to be the kind of person who gives others the same support my mom gave me.

Going through those interview questions felt like peeling back layers of who I am. Starting with the story of my life brought up so many memories—my childhood in Chicago, growing up in a single-parent household, and the quiet way I found solace in books. It was strange to hear myself talk about it all again, but it also felt necessary. When I talked about the crossroads in my life, the moment with Marcus, it hit me how much that decision still shapes me today. I didn't realize how much I still carry that feeling of responsibility to show up for others, even when it's hard. Thinking about the people who supported me—Dr. Alvarez, my mom, the kids I worked with—it reminded me how much I owe them. And when I talked about family, it made me reflect on how much I want to be the kind of person my mom was for me. These questions didn't just ask about my past; they made me think about who I am now and who I want to be moving forward.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Lauren Kallas: My father passed away when I was in high school, before I really understood how much his absence would shape my life. I didn't get to know him very well—he wasn't around much, and when he was, it was more about duty than connection. I remember my mom trying to explain it to me, but I was too young to grasp the full weight of it. Looking back, I think his absence taught me what it meant to be resilient, even if it wasn't something I wanted to learn at the time. I never had a close relationship with him, and I don't think he ever saw me as more than a responsibility. That's why I've always tried to be present for the people in my life, especially the kids I work with. I want them to know that someone is there for them, no matter what. It's a strange way to honor him, I guess, but it's the best way I know how.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Lauren Kallas: There are a few friends who have been there through the ups and downs, especially during my time in school and early in my career. One of them, Sarah, was my roommate in college, and we've stayed close ever since. She's the kind of person who knows when to push me and when to just listen. She's also the one who encouraged me to apply for that graduate program I ended up getting into. We don't see each other as often as I'd like, but when we do, it's like no time has passed. Then there's my coworker, Jamal—he's been a huge support in my current job. He's been in the field longer than I have, and he's always willing to offer advice or just have a conversation when things get overwhelming. I think the people who matter most to me are the ones who show up, even when life gets messy. They remind me that I'm not alone, and that makes all the difference.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Lauren Kallas: I live in a neighborhood on the West Side of Chicago, just a few blocks from where I grew up. It's a tight-knit community, but it's also one of the areas that's seen a lot of change over the years. There are still a lot of long-time residents, but there's also a growing population of young professionals and artists moving in, which has brought some new energy to the area. I live in a small apartment above a local bookstore, which is actually owned by an old friend of mine from college. It's a quiet place, and I like that—it gives me a sense of stability. The neighborhood isn't perfect, though. There are still issues with crime and economic disparity, which is why I feel so strongly about the work I do. Every day, I see the challenges people face, and it reminds me why I chose this path. I want to be part of the solution, even if it's just in small ways. I think the best thing about living here is that I'm surrounded by people who are fighting for a better future, just like I am.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Lauren Kallas: I feel safe here, but it's not the kind of safety that comes from ignoring the problems around you. It's more like a quiet resilience—knowing that even though things aren't perfect, there's a sense of community that keeps people grounded. I've lived in other parts of the city, and while some areas feel more 'safe' in the traditional sense, I think this neighborhood has something more real. People look out for each other, even if they don't always have the means to do much. I've seen neighbors help each other through tough times, whether it's fixing a broken fence or just offering a listening ear. That kind of safety, the kind that comes from connection, is what I value most. I don't think I'd feel as driven to do the work I do if I didn't live in a place where I saw both the struggles and the strength of the people around me every day.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Lauren Kallas: Living here has its challenges, but it's also where I feel most connected to who I am. There are days when I walk down the street and see kids playing in the park, and I think about Marcus and the others I've worked with over the years. It's humbling to see how much the neighborhood has shaped me, even if it hasn't always been easy. I love the energy of the place—the way the local coffee shop owner knows your order before you say it, or how the bookstore downstairs hosts poetry nights that bring the community together. But I also know the struggles that come with it. I've seen friends leave for better opportunities, and I've had to make tough decisions about my own future because of the financial instability that still lingers. Still, I wouldn't trade it for anything. This place has taught me resilience, and it's where I've found my purpose. I think that's why I keep coming back—to be part of the story, even if I'm just one chapter in it.

Going through the interview questions about my family, neighborhood, and sense of safety made me reflect on how deeply connected I am to the people and places that have shaped me. Talking about my mom, my cousins, and the absence of my father brought up a lot of emotions, but it also reminded me of the strength I've carried from my past. When I described my current neighborhood, I realized how much it still influences who I am—its struggles, its resilience, and the people who keep showing up for each other. It's strange how these questions made me feel both grounded and inspired, like I was reconnecting with parts of myself I hadn't fully acknowledged. I think I'm starting to see that my journey isn't just about the work I do, but also about the community I come from and the people who keep me rooted in it.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Lauren Kallas: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but it's also fluid depending on what's coming up at work. I start most mornings around 7 a.m., usually with a cup of coffee and a quick walk around the block to clear my head. I work full-time at a nonprofit that supports at-risk youth, so my days are pretty much the same—meetings, case reviews, and sometimes direct work with kids or their families. I try to leave the office by 5 p.m., but there are days when I stay late to wrap up a project or meet with a client. On the weekends, I like to spend time with my mom or my cousins, or I'll go to the bookstore where I live and just lose myself in a book for a few hours. I also try to volunteer at least once a month, whether it's helping out at a food pantry or just sitting with someone who needs a listening ear. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I think the rhythm of it keeps me grounded. I know I'm not where I want to be financially, and I still have a lot of student debt to pay off, but I feel like I'm doing something that matters. That, more than anything, keeps me going.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Lauren Kallas: I work full-time at a nonprofit organization called 'Bright Futures Chicago,' where I serve as a case manager for at-risk youth and their families. My days typically start at 8:30 a.m., and I work until around 5 p.m., though I often stay a bit later when there are urgent cases or meetings that need attention. The work is demanding—it involves coordinating with schools, social services, and community programs to ensure the kids we support have access to resources like counseling, tutoring, and stable housing. I also spend time visiting some of the kids in their homes or schools, which can be emotionally draining but also incredibly rewarding. I've learned to pace myself, but there are days when I feel like I'm running on fumes. Still, I keep going because I know how much it means to the kids I work with. I remember Marcus, the boy I told you about earlier—he's now in college, and he sends me updates every once in a while. Reading those messages is what keeps me going, even on the hardest days.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Lauren Kallas: Outside of work, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay balanced. I try to get to bed by 10 p.m. most nights, even if it means winding down with a book or some light meditation. I've found that sleep is something I can't afford to skimp on, especially with the emotional weight of the work I do. I also make it a point to cook at least one meal a week from scratch—usually something my mom used to make when I was growing up. It's a small way to honor her, and it reminds me of where I came from. On the weekends, when I'm not with family, I like to take long walks through the park near my apartment. It's a quiet place, and it helps me process everything that's going on in my life. I think the key to surviving this kind of work is having these little rituals—things that ground you when the world feels too heavy. I don't know if I'd be able to keep going without them.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Lauren Kallas: One of the biggest changes to my routine has been starting to incorporate more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I used to just grab my coffee and rush out the door, but I've been trying to slow down and take a few minutes to breathe deeply or do a short meditation before I start my day. It's something I picked up after a particularly tough month at work, when I felt like I was constantly on edge. I remember coming home one night and just breaking down in tears—I realized I hadn't taken a real moment for myself in weeks. My friend Sarah suggested I try mindfulness, and it's been a game-changer. Now, even if it's just five minutes, I make time to center myself. It doesn't fix everything, but it helps me show up more fully for the people I care about and the work I do. I think it's a small but meaningful shift that's helping me stay grounded in all the chaos.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Lauren Kallas: I don't have children of my own yet, but I've spent a lot of time with kids through my work, and it's shaped my understanding of what a typical day might look like for a child in a family like mine. If I did have children, I would want them to have a routine that balanced structure with creativity. I imagine them waking up early, maybe around 7 a.m., with a healthy breakfast and a few minutes of quiet time before school. I'd want them to feel grounded, so maybe some light reading or journaling. Then, they'd head off to school, and after school, I'd want them to have time to explore their interests—whether that's art, music, or sports. I'd also make sure they had time to just be kids, to play outside or hang out with friends. I think the most important thing would be for them to feel supported, both academically and emotionally. I've seen so many kids struggle without that kind of stability, and I want to make sure my children never feel that way. If I had the chance to parent, it would be about creating a safe space where they could grow, make mistakes, and still feel loved.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how deeply my sense of self is tied to the people and places that have shaped me. Talking about my family, especially my mom and the absence of my father, brought up a lot of emotions, but it also reminded me of the strength I've carried from my past. Describing my current neighborhood and the challenges it faces made me realize how much it still influences who I am—its struggles, its resilience, and the people who keep showing up for each other. It's strange how these questions made me feel both grounded and inspired, like I was reconnecting with parts of myself I hadn't fully acknowledged. I think I'm starting to see that my journey isn't just about the work I do, but also about the community I come from and the people who keep me rooted in it. Reflecting on my daily routines and responsibilities also made me appreciate the small rituals that help me stay balanced—whether it's cooking a meal from scratch, taking a walk in the park, or practicing mindfulness in the morning. These things may seem simple, but they are what keep me going when the work feels heavy. I think I'm beginning to understand that my purpose isn't just about helping others—it's also about honoring the people and places that have shaped me into who I am today.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Lauren Kallas: My health has been something I've had to be pretty intentional about, especially with the demands of my job. I used to push through exhaustion or stress without really thinking about it, but over the past few years, I've learned the hard way that burnout is real and it doesn't just go away on its own. I've had a few instances where I ignored my body's signals—like when I started getting chronic migraines from working too many hours without rest. That was a wake-up call. Now, I try to prioritize regular check-ups, even if it's just a routine visit to the doctor. I also make sure to eat well, even on busy days—though I'll admit, I'm not perfect at it. I've started incorporating more plant-based meals into my diet, partly because I want to feel better physically, but also because I think it's better for the environment. I also try to stay active, whether it's a quick jog around the neighborhood or a yoga class on the weekends. It's not always easy, but I've come to see my health as a non-negotiable part of being able to show up for the people I care about. I don't want to be the kind of person who puts everyone else first and forgets to take care of myself in the process.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Lauren Kallas: What makes it easy to stay healthy is knowing that my well-being directly impacts the people I care about—the kids I work with, my mom, and even the community I'm part of. When I take care of myself, I show up more fully for them. But what makes it hard is the constant pressure to do more, to be more, even when I'm already stretched thin. There are days when I feel like I'm running on empty, and I have to remind myself that taking a break isn't a failure—it's a necessity. I think the hardest part is also the most important: learning to say no to things that don't align with my health or my values. It's not always easy, especially in a field where people are constantly asking for more of you, but I'm trying to be more intentional about what I commit to. I'm still figuring it out, but I know that if I don't take care of myself, I won't be able to take care of anyone else.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Lauren Kallas: In the past two years, I've dealt with a few health challenges that have forced me to slow down and really listen to my body. The biggest thing was a flare-up of the chronic migraines I started getting a few years ago. They used to come once in a while, but they've become more frequent and intense, especially during stressful periods at work. I remember one particularly bad week where I had three migraines in a row, and I had to take a few days off just to recover. It was frustrating because I felt like I was letting the kids I work with down, but I realized that if I wasn't well, I couldn't be fully present for them. I also started seeing a therapist for the first time, which has been really helpful in managing the stress and emotional weight of my job. It's not something I ever thought I needed before, but I've come to see mental health as just as important as physical health. I've also been dealing with some lingering back pain from years of sitting at a desk for long hours, and I finally made the decision to start seeing a physical therapist. It's been a process, but I'm learning that taking care of myself isn't a sign of weakness—it's a way of honoring the people who depend on me.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Lauren Kallas: Honestly, there have been times when my health issues made it harder to do the work I love, and that's not something I take lightly. When I was dealing with those migraines, I had to cancel a few meetings and even miss a few days at work. It was hard because I felt like I was failing the kids I was trying to help. But what I've come to realize is that showing up for them doesn't mean being perfect—it means being present, even if that means taking a step back sometimes. I've also had to adjust how I manage my time and energy, which has been a learning process. I used to think I had to be strong all the time, but now I see that strength also comes from knowing when to ask for help. I've started setting clearer boundaries at work, and I've learned to say no to things that don't align with my well-being. It's not always easy, but I'm starting to see that taking care of myself isn't just about me—it's about being able to show up for the people who need me most, even when I'm not at my best.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Lauren Kallas: Over the past year, I've been feeling a mix of things—some days I feel really grounded and purposeful, and other days I feel like I'm just barely keeping my head above water. The work I do is deeply meaningful, but it also takes a toll. I've been trying to be more intentional about how I care for myself, which has helped, but there are still moments when I feel overwhelmed by the weight of it all. I think the biggest shift for me has been learning to accept that I can't do everything, and that's okay. I've started to let go of some of the guilt I used to feel when I had to take a step back or say no to something. That's been hard, but it's also been healing. I've also been reconnecting with parts of myself that I had pushed aside for so long—like my love for reading, or just sitting in silence and reflecting. I think I'm starting to see that taking care of my mental and emotional health isn't just about surviving—it's about living fully, even when the path isn't easy.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and well-being are intertwined with the work I do and the people I care about. Talking about my recent changes in routine, like incorporating mindfulness into my mornings, reminded me of how small shifts can have a big impact on how I show up for myself and others. When I discussed my health struggles—like the migraines and back pain—it brought up a lot of feelings about the pressure I put on myself to be strong and always available. But it also reminded me that taking care of my body and mind isn't a weakness—it's a way of honoring the people who depend on me. I think I'm finally starting to understand that I can't pour from an empty cup, and that taking time for myself isn't selfish—it's necessary. It's strange how these questions made me feel both vulnerable and empowered, like I was finally giving myself permission to prioritize my health without guilt. I'm still learning, but I'm beginning to see that my well-being is just as important as the work I do, and that's something I need to keep reminding myself of every day.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Lauren Kallas: I think I've struggled with anxiety more than anything else, though I didn't always recognize it for what it was. For a long time, I thought it was just part of the job—being hyper-aware of the challenges people face, the weight of responsibility, the pressure to do more with less. But over the past year, I've started to see it for what it is: a constant undercurrent of worry that I can't always shake. It shows up in little ways—tightness in my chest when I'm overwhelmed, trouble sleeping even when I'm not working late, or feeling like I'm constantly on edge, even when I'm sitting still. I used to push through it, thinking I had to be strong for the kids I work with, but I've come to realize that acknowledging my own struggles doesn't make me any less capable. In fact, it makes me more human. I've started seeing a therapist, and it's been a slow but important process of learning how to sit with my thoughts instead of running from them. I still have days where the anxiety feels like a heavy fog, but I'm learning that it doesn't define me—it's just one part of who I am, and I'm working on making space for the rest.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Lauren Kallas: For my family, it's been a mix of support and concern. My mom has always been there for me, but I think she's worried about the toll this work takes on me. She doesn't say it out loud, but I can tell by the way she checks in on me more often—asking if I'm eating, if I'm sleeping, if I'm still okay. She knows what it's like to carry a lot without asking for help, and I think she sees herself in me sometimes. My cousins, on the other hand, have been more focused on their own lives—some are in school, others are starting careers, and they're all trying to figure out what they want. But even with their own struggles, they still make time for me. They remind me that I'm not alone, even when I feel like I'm carrying everything. I think the hardest part for them is seeing me push myself so hard, even when I'm not at my best. They want me to take care of myself, but they also know how much I care about the work I do. It's a delicate balance, but I'm grateful for their love and support. I think that's what family is—showing up, even when you don't have all the answers.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Lauren Kallas: I was raised Catholic, but I haven't been religious since I was in high school. I always felt like I didn't quite fit in with the more traditional parts of the church, and I guess that's when I started questioning a lot of things. Over time, I drifted away from organized religion, but I still find meaning in the idea of connection—whether it's with other people, the world around me, or even with myself. I don't think of it as spirituality in the traditional sense, but I do believe in the importance of being present, of showing up for others, and of finding purpose in the small moments. I think that's what my mom taught me, even if she was still very much a person of faith. I respect that part of her, but I've come to see my own kind of faith as something more personal, something that lives in the way I treat others and the choices I make every day.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Lauren Kallas: I don't use social media very often, honestly. I used to be on Facebook more when I was in school, mostly to stay in touch with friends and family, but over time, I found myself getting caught up in the noise—comparing my life to others, feeling like I wasn't doing enough, or seeing things that just made me more anxious. I tried Instagram once, but it felt like it only added to the pressure of being 'present' all the time. Now, I mostly use Facebook to keep in touch with my mom and cousins, and maybe check in on old friends once in a while. I don't follow a lot of accounts, and when I do, it's usually ones that share stories about community work or mental health, because those are the things that resonate with me. I think I've come to see social media as something that can be useful, but also something that can take away from the real connections I already have. I'd rather spend my time talking to someone face-to-face or reading a book than scrolling through my phone all night.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Lauren Kallas: Honestly, I don't think I've ever really relied on social media for support, even during tough times. I know that sounds strange, but I've always found comfort in the people I know in real life—my mom, my friends, the coworkers who understand what this work is like. I've seen how social media can be a double-edged sword, and I don't want to get caught up in the comparison or the noise. That said, I do think it can be a tool for connection if used mindfully. For example, I've followed a few mental health advocates online whose posts have helped me feel less alone sometimes. But I've never posted about my struggles publicly or sought out emotional support through those platforms. I prefer to talk things out face-to-face, even if it's just a phone call. I think there's something about the vulnerability of sharing your struggles in person that feels more real, more honest. I don't know if I'd ever be the kind of person to turn to social media for support, but I respect that others do. It's just not my way.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect deeply on how my health and emotional well-being are intertwined with the work I do and the people I care about. Talking about my recent health challenges—like the migraines and back pain—forced me to confront the pressure I've always put on myself to be strong and constantly available. It was hard to admit that I wasn't always okay, but it also reminded me that taking care of my body and mind isn't a weakness—it's a way of honoring the people who depend on me. When I discussed my struggles with anxiety, it brought up a lot of feelings about how I've carried that weight for so long, thinking I had to be perfect for the kids I work with. But now I see that acknowledging my own struggles doesn't make me any less capable—it makes me more human. I'm still learning, but I'm beginning to understand that I can't pour from an empty cup, and that taking time for myself isn't selfish—it's necessary. These questions made me feel both vulnerable and empowered, like I was finally giving myself permission to prioritize my health without guilt. I'm still figuring it out, but I'm starting to see that my well-being is just as important as the work I do, and that's something I need to keep reminding myself of every day.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Lauren Kallas: In the past year, my stress levels have definitely fluctuated, but I think I've become more aware of how I handle it. There were times when I felt like I was carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders, especially during the holidays when the work got busier and I was trying to balance everything else. But I've started to notice patterns—when I'm overwhelmed, it's not just the workload, it's the emotional toll of seeing the same struggles in the kids I work with, over and over again. I've been trying to build better coping strategies, like journaling more often or taking short breaks during the day to breathe and reset. I also started seeing a therapist, which has been really helpful in unpacking some of the guilt and anxiety I carry. It's not like I've completely mastered it, but I feel like I'm learning how to be kinder to myself when things get heavy. I think the biggest shift has been realizing that it's okay to not be okay all the time, and that taking a moment to pause doesn't mean I'm failing—it means I'm still trying.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Lauren Kallas: My biggest expenses last month were rent, groceries, and student loan payments. I live in a small apartment above the bookstore, and the rent is manageable, but it still takes up a good chunk of my paycheck. Groceries are another thing—since I try to eat well and cook at least one meal from scratch each week, that adds up, especially when I'm buying fresh produce and whole foods. Student loans are definitely the heaviest part of my monthly budget. I took out a lot of debt to finish my graduate degree, and even though I'm working full-time now, it's still a constant reminder of the financial sacrifices I made to be in this field. I also set aside money for public transportation, since I don't own a car, and I try to contribute a little to my mom's expenses when I can. It's not much, but I want her to know I'm still thinking of her. I've also started setting aside a small amount each month for personal care and mental health—therapy, self-care items, things like that. It's not always easy to balance everything, but I try to be intentional about where my money goes. I know I'm not where I want to be financially, but I also know that this work is worth it, even if it takes longer to see the payoff.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Lauren Kallas: My household spending last month was around $2,800, which is pretty close to what I usually spend each month. The majority of that goes to rent, which is about $1,200, and groceries, which hover around $600. Student loan payments are another big chunk—around $400 a month. I also spend about $200 on public transportation and utilities, and I try to set aside $100 for personal care and mental health, like therapy sessions or buying books. The rest goes toward miscellaneous expenses, like clothing or small gifts for my mom or cousins. It's not a lot, but it's enough to get by. I know I'm not in a position of financial stability yet, but I'm learning to be more mindful of where my money goes. I used to be really tight with everything, but I've come to see that investing in myself—whether it's through therapy, food, or even just a new book—can be just as important as paying the bills. It's a balancing act, but I'm trying to make it work.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Lauren Kallas: We rent our home. I live in a small apartment above a local bookstore, which is actually owned by an old friend of mine from college. It's a quiet place, and I like that—it gives me a sense of stability. Rent is about $1,200 a month, which is manageable but still takes up a good chunk of my paycheck. I've considered buying a place someday, but right now, renting feels more practical. I don't want to tie up all my savings in a mortgage when I'm still paying off student loans and trying to build a stable career. Plus, living in a rented space gives me the flexibility to stay close to the community I care about, and I don't think I'd want to move far away from that. It's not perfect, but it works for me.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Lauren Kallas: Over the past year, my bills have had their ups and downs, mostly tied to the seasons and the rhythm of life here. In the winter, heating costs go up, and I notice that my utility bill increases by about $50 to $75 compared to other months. I also tend to spend a bit more on groceries during the holidays, especially when I cook bigger meals or buy gifts for my mom and cousins. Then there are the months when I have to pay for things like therapy sessions or professional development courses, which are usually spread out over the year. I also noticed that during the summer, when the neighborhood hosts community events or festivals, I end up spending a little more on things like concert tickets or supporting local businesses. But overall, my expenses stay pretty consistent, with the exception of those seasonal fluctuations. I've learned to budget for these changes, even if it's just a small amount each month, and it helps me feel more in control of my finances. It's not about having a lot—it's about knowing exactly where my money is going and making sure I'm not caught off guard when things shift.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply my health, emotional well-being, and relationships are connected. Talking about my family, especially my mom and cousins, reminded me of the support system I have, even when I feel like I'm carrying everything on my own. It also made me realize how much I've relied on them, not just for emotional support but for grounding me when I feel lost in the noise of my work and life. When I discussed my health struggles, like the migraines and back pain, it brought up the pressure I've always put on myself to be strong and constantly available. But it also reminded me that taking care of my body and mind isn't a weakness—it's a way of honoring the people who depend on me. I think I'm finally starting to understand that I can't pour from an empty cup, and that taking time for myself isn't selfish—it's necessary. I'm still learning, but I'm beginning to see that my well-being is just as important as the work I do, and that's something I need to keep reminding myself of every day.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Lauren Kallas: I do have a savings account, though it's not a huge amount. I try to set aside whatever I can each month, even if it's just a small portion of my paycheck. Right now, I'm aiming for around $100 a month, which goes into a separate account that I don't touch unless it's an emergency. It's not much, but it gives me a little peace of mind knowing that there's something there if I need it. I used to be really bad about not saving at all, thinking that as long as I could cover my bills, I was fine. But after a few rough months where I had to dip into my emergency fund for unexpected expenses, I realized that even small savings can make a difference. I also try to save in other ways—like buying secondhand clothes or using coupons when I can. It's not about being rich, it's about being prepared. I know I'm not in a position to have a lot, but I'm learning that even small steps toward financial stability can add up over time.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Lauren Kallas: In the last year, I've been saving more with the intention of having a rainy day fund, rather than for a big purchase like a home. I know buying a place is something I might want to do someday, but right now, it feels out of reach. Instead, I focus on building a small emergency fund so that if something unexpected comes up—like a sudden medical expense or a repair I can't afford to ignore—I won't have to dig into my student loans or compromise my mental health by taking on extra work. I also try to save a little bit for personal growth, like buying books or attending workshops that help me be a better professional and person. It's not about having a lot—it's about being prepared, even in small ways. I think that's the kind of security I need to keep going, especially in a field where the emotional demands can be so high.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Lauren Kallas: My occupation is as a case manager at a nonprofit organization called 'Bright Futures Chicago,' where I work with at-risk youth and their families. The most important part of my job is building trust—whether it's with the kids I work with, their families, or the other professionals I collaborate with. I spend a lot of time listening, not just to what people say, but to what they don't say. That's where a lot of the real work happens. I coordinate with schools, social services, and community programs to make sure the kids we support have access to resources like counseling, tutoring, and stable housing. I also spend time visiting some of the kids in their homes or schools, which can be emotionally draining but also incredibly rewarding. One of the hardest parts of the job is knowing that no matter how much we do, there are still so many barriers these kids face—systemic issues, poverty, lack of access to mental health care. But I also find strength in the resilience of the kids I work with. They remind me why I chose this path, and I try to be a steady presence in their lives, even when things feel overwhelming. It's not always easy, but I keep going because I know how much it means to them.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Lauren Kallas: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, though it can sometimes stretch into 60 if there are urgent cases or meetings that need attention. My schedule is pretty consistent—Monday through Friday, starting at 8:30 a.m. and ending around 5 p.m., but I often stay late when I need to wrap up a project or meet with a client. The work is demanding, and I've learned to pace myself, but there are days when I feel like I'm running on fumes. Still, I keep going because I know how much it means to the kids I work with. I remember Marcus, the boy I told you about earlier—he's now in college, and he sends me updates every once in a while. Reading those messages is what keeps me going, even on the hardest days.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Lauren Kallas: No, I haven't had more than one job in recent years. I've been fully committed to my work at Bright Futures Chicago, and while I used to take on part-time gigs in college to help make ends meet, I've found that focusing on one role allows me to be more present for the kids and families I serve. There were a few times when I considered freelancing or taking on extra shifts at the bookstore where I live, but I always ended up saying no. I think it's because I know how much this work demands—not just in terms of time, but also emotionally. I don't want to spread myself too thin, especially when I know how much it means to be fully there for the people I care about. I've learned that for me, quality of presence matters more than quantity of work.

Talking about my stress levels and the emotional toll of my work reminded me of how much I've been carrying, not just professionally, but also personally. At the same time, discussing my monthly budget and expenses brought up the reality of living on a tight financial margin, which adds another layer of pressure. I've always believed that the work I do is worth it, but it's not without its sacrifices. I've had to make tough choices about where to allocate my money, and sometimes it feels like I'm constantly choosing between paying my bills and investing in myself. But I'm learning that even small steps—like setting aside money for therapy or buying a book—can make a difference. These questions made me feel both vulnerable and grounded, like I was finally giving myself permission to acknowledge the weight I carry without feeling like I have to fix everything all at once. Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Lauren Kallas: In total, my household made around $3,200 in the past month. That comes from my full-time salary at Bright Futures Chicago, which is just enough to cover my rent, groceries, and student loan payments, but not much more. I try to live within my means, and I've gotten pretty good at tracking my expenses, but there are still days when I feel like I'm constantly choosing between paying my bills and investing in myself. I've started setting aside a small portion of my paycheck for things like therapy or books, which I used to think were luxuries. But I've come to see them as necessary—like fuel for the work I do. It's not a lot, but it's enough to keep me going, and I'm learning to be more intentional about how I spend what I have. I know I'm not where I want to be financially, but I also know that this work is worth it, even if it takes longer to see the payoff.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Lauren Kallas: I've been at Bright Futures Chicago for about three years now, and it's been both a challenge and a privilege. The benefits package isn't anything extravagant, but it's enough to get by. I have health insurance, which is a huge relief, especially with the migraines and back pain I've been dealing with. I also get a few weeks of paid vacation and sick time each year, which I try to use wisely. I know how easy it is to burn out in this line of work, so I make sure to take those days when I need to, even if it means stepping away from the chaos for a little while. The most important thing about this job, though, is the sense of purpose it gives me. I don't make a lot of money, and I definitely don't have the luxury of a lot of perks, but I feel like I'm doing something that matters. That, more than anything, keeps me going.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Lauren Kallas: My relationships at work are pretty much what I need them to be—supportive, but not without its challenges. I have a good relationship with my manager, Ms. Thompson. She's been in the field for a long time, and she knows the weight of this work. She doesn't always have the answers, but she's always willing to listen and offer guidance when I need it. I think she sees me as someone who's committed, even if I don't always have the easiest time with the emotional toll. As for my coworkers, we have a mix of people—some have been here for years, others are newer like me. We all have different styles, but there's a shared understanding that this job isn't just about the tasks we do; it's about the people we're trying to help. I have a few close coworkers, like Jamal, who I mentioned earlier. He's been a huge support, not just professionally but personally. We've had long conversations about the struggles of this work, and I think that kind of connection is rare in a place like this. There are days when the relationships feel strained, especially when we're all stretched thin, but I think that's just part of the reality. What matters most is that I feel like I can show up as myself, even when things get hard.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Lauren Kallas: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but it's not without its flexibility. I usually start at 8:30 a.m. and end around 5 p.m., but there are days when I stay late to wrap up a case or meet with a client. My manager understands that this work doesn't always fit into a strict 9-to-5 framework, especially when we're dealing with kids who need support outside of regular hours. That said, there are also times when I have to adjust my schedule for meetings or trainings, which can be a bit unpredictable. I appreciate the flexibility because it allows me to be present for the people I work with, even if it means staying late or coming in early. But I also know that this kind of flexibility can be a double-edged sword—when you're always on call, it's hard to truly disconnect. I've had to learn how to set boundaries, even if it's just knowing when to say no to extra work so I can take care of myself. It's a balance I'm still figuring out, but I think it's one of the things that makes this job both challenging and rewarding.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Lauren Kallas: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is a constant balancing act—something I'm still learning to navigate. I know I'm not in a position of wealth, and I don't expect to be anytime soon, but I also know that this work is worth it, even if it doesn't pay as much as I'd like. There are days when I feel frustrated by the financial sacrifices I've made, like the student loans that still loom over me or the fact that I can't afford to take a real vacation without planning for months. But then I think about the kids I work with, the ones who have so much less than I do, and I realize that my struggles are nothing compared to what they face. I'm learning to be more intentional with my money, to see it not just as something I need to survive, but as something that can help me grow—whether that's through therapy, books, or even just a small treat that reminds me I'm still here, still trying. I don't know what the future holds financially, but I do know that I'm not going to let that define who I am or what I'm capable of. I'm still figuring it out, but I'm getting better at finding ways to make this life work, even if it's not always easy.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Lauren Kallas: Yes, my mom worked for pay for at least a year while I was growing up, and honestly, she worked pretty much every year since I was a kid. She was a receptionist at a local clinic, and while it wasn't a high-paying job, she always made sure we had what we needed. I remember her working long hours, sometimes coming home exhausted, but she never complained. She just kept going, always putting her own needs aside for mine. I think that's why I've always felt such a strong sense of responsibility to show up for the people I work with—to be there, even when it's hard. It's strange how much of who I am today comes from watching her do that, even though I didn't always understand it at the time. I guess I carry a lot of her strength with me, even if I'm still learning how to use it in my own way.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Lauren Kallas: My mom worked as a receptionist at a local clinic, and while it wasn't a high-paying job, she was incredibly dedicated. Her most important duties were greeting patients, scheduling appointments, and making sure everyone felt seen and heard. She had a way of making people feel at ease, even when they were in pain or distress. I remember watching her handle difficult situations with grace—whether it was calming a scared child or comforting a parent who was worried about their loved one. She always said that her job wasn't just about taking calls or filing paperwork; it was about being a presence for people who needed someone to talk to, even if just for a moment. That kind of quiet strength, that belief in the power of showing up for others, is something I carry with me every day. I think that's why I chose this path—it's the same kind of work she did, just in a different way. She never had the chance to do the kind of hands-on support I do now, but she always believed in the importance of helping people, even in small ways. I think that's why I feel so connected to the kids I work with, because I see my mom in them, and I want to be the kind of person she was for me.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Lauren Kallas: My mom worked at a small community clinic in our neighborhood, one of those places that felt like a second home to a lot of people. It wasn't a big hospital or anything like that—it was more of a family-run clinic, and the staff there knew everyone by name. She did a lot more than just take calls or schedule appointments. She was the first face people saw when they walked in, and she made sure they felt like they mattered. I remember her telling me once that even if someone came in with just a cold, she wanted them to leave feeling like they had been heard. She always said that the work she did wasn't just about the paperwork or the phone calls—it was about being there for people, even if it was just for a few minutes. That kind of quiet dedication, that belief in the power of showing up for others, is something I carry with me every day. I think that's why I chose this path—it's the same kind of work she did, just in a different way. She never had the chance to do the kind of hands-on support I do now, but she always believed in the importance of helping people, even in small ways. I think that's why I feel so connected to the kids I work with, because I see my mom in them, and I want to be the kind of person she was for me.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Lauren Kallas: A few years from now, I hope I'm still doing the work I love, but with a little more stability—maybe a bigger role at Bright Futures Chicago, or even the chance to lead a program that makes a real difference in the lives of the kids we serve. I hope I'm still living in this neighborhood, still surrounded by the people who keep me grounded. I want to be the kind of person my mom was for me—someone who shows up, even when it's hard, and who believes in the power of small acts of kindness. I also hope I'm better at taking care of myself, not just physically but emotionally. I want to be the kind of person who can say no when I need to, who can take a break without feeling guilty, and who can still find joy in the little things—like a good book, a walk in the park, or just sitting with someone who needs to be heard. I don't know exactly what the future holds, but I hope it's one where I'm still learning, still growing, and still trying to make a difference, even if it's just one life at a time.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Lauren Kallas: What I value the most in my life is connection—real, meaningful connection with people. Whether it's my mom, the kids I work with, my friends, or even the neighbors I pass by on my walk, I think the most important thing is knowing that I'm not alone. I've spent so much of my life trying to be there for others, sometimes at the expense of my own needs, but I've come to realize that the strongest relationships are the ones where we show up for each other, even when it's hard. I value the quiet moments—the ones where someone just listens, or where you can sit in silence without feeling the need to fill the space. I also value resilience, because I've seen so much of it in the people I care about, and I want to be someone who embodies that too. It's not about being perfect or having everything figured out—it's about showing up, even when you're not sure what the next step is. That, more than anything, is what I hold onto.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been like looking in a mirror I hadn't really seen clearly in a long time.
